pr_title: [participant-manager-datastore]: [POST] "/users", [PUT] "/users/{adminUserId}/" and [POST] "/users/{userId}/invite" end points refactored with email scheduler task implementation

timeline.message: email scheduler task and and code refactored

timeline.bodyText: Even with the foreign key constraints, I would still suggest you use query injections for consistency with the project. If not, please shorten this comment to one line.
timeline.author: saminguyen

replies.bodyText:
I want to emphasize on Sami's comment. SQL injection has nothing to do with foreignKey, and having foreign keys does not resolve the need to have good security.
We just went through a painful scrubbing of the code to fix exactly these issues; you need to make sure to not introduce new security issues like this one in future.
As far as I am concerned, this PR is completely unacceptable and all query generations need to be redone with security at the forefront. Please fix this and any other similar shortcuts you have taken.
replies.author: zohrehj

replies.bodyText:
@zohrehj @saminguyen This API was taking more time for JPA based implementation. I referred this link Bulk RDBMS Upserts with Spring  section #Extra: Further Improving batch inserts.
Before adopting this approach, we discussed about SQL Injection possibilities hence we left the comment in PR.
This is the only API we used string-based query approach to improve the API performance and wanted to discuss this on Thursday's call. I didn't see any security risks with this approach for this API.
I've asked developers to keep SQL Injections and XSS in mind while implementing the features or issues fixes.
Please review the PR or we can discuss this in tomorrow's call.
replies.author: dhanyak-btc

timeline.author: saminguyen
saminguyen

timeline.message: add and update user api refactored with batch operation
property file changed for batch operation and site entity changed

timeline.author: saminguyen

timeline.bodyText: Consider using HashMap here instead for efficiency when calling contains()
timeline.author: saminguyen

replies.bodyText:
@saminguyen I agree with you, HashMap is faster than ArrayList for contains() method, the time difference will be  in nanoseconds as the List size is small so it doesn't make big difference in API response time. Also, we are not using Key-Value pairs to use HashMap.
We noticed all the performance issues are due to too many SQL calls to database so we refactored the code to minimize the database calls. Please note, Batch operations take more seconds compared to Bulk Insert. Please review & approve the PR once Chiranjibi fixes other review comments.
replies.author: dhanyak-btc
